speakers.name: Rosie Hamilton
speakers.title: Discovering Logic in Testing
speakers.abstract: We all test in different ways and sometimes it can be hard to explain the thought processes behind how we test. What leads us into trying certain things and how do we draw conclusions, surely there is more going on here than intuition and luck? After working in games testing for almost a decade, Rosie draws from experience to explain how games testers develop advanced logical reasoning skills. Using practical examples that will make you think, she will demonstrate logical patterns, rules and concepts that can help all of us gain a deeper understanding of what is actually happening in our minds when we test.
speakers.bio: I currently work as a Senior Test Engineer at Scott Logic in Newcastle. I've been testing since 2005 and survived 9 years in the UK Games Industry having worked for Xbox, 2K Games & Blizzard Entertainment. I've previously spoken at Newcastle Agile Testing, Agile North East and South West Test meet-ups. My hobbies include violin and yoga.

speakers.name: Chris Warren
speakers.title: To the left to the left, Everything I test in a box to the left...
speakers.abstract: I would like to tell my story about how I started focusing my attention on the right side of the board but slowly started to shift to the left. The journey starts with me picking up work in the ‘Test’ column without much involvement earlier in the process and continues today with me spending most of my time testing the requirements in an Analysis stage and working with the team to ensure testing is baked in throughout the process.
speakers.bio: I’ve been a software test consultant for nearly 8 years working in a variety of sectors across numerous roles mainly in performance and automation. My current engagement is for a consumer finance company who want to give their major platform a facelift. I’m part of an alleged scrum team tasked with breaking down the businesses epics and turning them into working software.

speakers.name: Andy Stewart
speakers.title: The Villains of Automated Testing
speakers.abstract: Patterns are used in software all the time. They give us a common language or set of practises for doing things. Sometimes it's hard to tell a good pattern from a bad (or anti) pattern. We implement something that seems like a good idea at the time and then replicate it across the project before realising it causes us huge problems further down the line. In this talk we discuss some of the common anti patterns seen in automated testing and how we can refactor them away.
speakers.bio: I have been involved in Software Delivery since I graduated in the year 2000 from Sheffield University. In 2007 I joined a startup called Erudine that practised eXtreme Programming (XP) and was introduced to TDD and pair programming. From then on testing is something I have become hugely passionate about and believe it's the responsibility of the entire team. These days I am CTO at Quantbet which is just a fancy way of saying I am responsible for the Software Delivery side of things AND get the phone call when the office internet goes down.

speakers.name: Luke Bonnacorsi
speakers.title: Testing with Snapshots
speakers.abstract: In June 2016, Facebook introduced snapshot testing into Jest, it’s JavaScript unit testing framework. Since then, snapshot testing has seen massive uptake because it makes writing tests for things like React way easier. In this talk I’ll go through what snapshot testing is, how it works and when to use it. I’ll be covering examples using React as well as non-React uses and hopefully you’ll gain the same enthusiasm I have for snapshot testing!
speakers.bio: Software Engineer at Sky Betting and Gaming, JavaScripter, eater, proud beard owner, swear enthusiast. Host and organiser of LeedsJS. I automated my curtains with JavaScript.

speakers.name: Richie Lee
speakers.title: Decoupling from implementation in BDD
speakers.abstract: With BDD and gherkin becoming staple tools in a tester's toolbox, it's a good idea to look at how we are currently using them and the pitfalls of testing so close to our software.  I invite people to join me as we look at how abstracting out our test steps allows for much more readable and flexible tests, which are easier to maintain as our software evolves.
speakers.bio: A former student of DeMontfort University, I have been a software tester now for 4 years. Working the majority of that for EMIS Health before recently moving to Sky Betting and Gaming. I'm currently working for a team which focuses on backend services delivery in node.js and, for my sins, php.

speakers.name: Jenny Gwilliam
speakers.title: Software Testing – a trip down memory lane
speakers.abstract: Ever wondered how much testing has changed over the years? Have the fundamentals altered much? And just how did we test before we had electronic test tools, email and instant results at our finger tips.  Jenny shares her experiences and gives her insight into a world of software testing in the Eighties to help give some food for thought about what perhaps has and hasn’t changed about our role.
speakers.bio: I was a consultant Test Manager for 18 years and before that a software tester for 10 years both in the UK and overseas.  I’ve worked in v-model, waterfall, agile environments in both private and public sectors, set up test departments from scratch and trained new Testers and Managers. In recent years, I switched career into Scrum Master with a key focus on coaching and training. Outside of work I can be found walking my dog, playing Softball, or kitted out as a 17th Century re-enactor.
